title: Vodafone charged me £60 for an international call that never took place
text:
A Vodafone customer was shocked to find he had been charged £60 after missing a mystery call from a Taiwanese number, but the mobile phone giant refused to refund him.

Didier, a 55-year-old from Ealing, received a call a couple of weeks ago from an international number in Taiwan, however, he didn't answer as he suspected it could be a spam call.

Later that evening, he received a text from Vodafone informing him that his monthly spend was higher than usual.

After checking his bill, he found there was a call lasting half an hour on there, costing him £60.

Mystery mobile charges have been reported in recent years from missed calls (stock image)

He contacted Vodafone to contest the charge but they assured him that the call had taken place.

Didier says that although the call shows up as taking place on his bill, he didn't answer the call or even use his phone much that day.

He claims Vodafone told him that as it was on his call log, it must have taken place and there is no way that it is a scam.

A Vodafone UK spokesperson said: 'We have looked into the charges relating to the customer's bill and can see that an outbound call was made from the UK lasting 30 minutes.

'As international minutes are not part of the customer's preferred plan, we sent a notification during the call advising of the additional charges for making this call.

'Our investigations team were also able to confirm that no fraudulent activity took place. We are in contact with the customer to resolve the matter and have offered to reduce the charges by 50 per cent as a gesture of goodwill.'

Despite the goodwill offer, Didier is concerned about how a call without his permission could have allegedly taken place.

He is not the first to be stung by a supposed scam like this as the Daily Mail has previously reported on a similar scam – many victims of which were also Vodafone customers.

Another similar scam that has affected a number of people is the Wangiri scam, where victims call fraudsters back after receiving an unknown call, usually from an international number.

The victim then ends up spending a fortune for every minute they are spent on the line after they are unwittingly directed to a premium rate overseas number.

Some mobile phone users have reported being charged after calling back an unknown number

What you can do to protect yourself from phone scams

With a growing number of fraudulent calls being reported, there are steps you can take to protect yourself from phone scams and unwanted callers.

Firstly, talk to your phone provider to see what call blocking services they offer. It may be worth shopping around as different providers have different charges.

Also, sign up to the Telephone Preference Service (TPS) which allows consumers to opt out of receiving any unsolicited telesales calls.

You can register your phone number – either landline or mobile – on the TPS website or by phoning 0345 070 0707. It's free to register and takes up to 28 days to come into effect.

Another way to protect yourself is by being wary of who you give your contact details to and what you are agreeing to when responding to marketing texts.

This is also the case for any emails received - make sure to look at the opt in and opt out boxes at the bottom to see what you are actually agreeing to.

What to do if you've received an unwanted call

Ofcom have recommended a number of things you can do if you have received a dodgy call ,or are suspicious of a missed call.

Firstly, if you do notice a call from an overseas number, don't answer or return it unless you know where it is coming from.

You should also block any unfamiliar overseas and premium-rate numbers and share them with your phone company, so they can investigate.

It is then worth contacting the Phone-paid Services Authority (PSA) with any suspicious activity, as it is the regulatory body for all premium rate phone-paid services in the United Kingdom. It can therefore look into any complaints and identify issues in the phone-paid services market.

Also, make sure to check your phone bills regularly to see if any money has come out that shouldn't.

Ofcom also suggest reporting the incident to Action Fraud.
